awd_titl_txt: RSB: Performance-based Decision Support System for Resilient and Sustainable Multi-Hazard Building Design
awd_abstract_narration:
The high social, economic, and environmental impacts associated with events such as the 2011 Tohoku, Japan earthquake and tsunami, and 2012 Hurricane Sandy are unsustainable. To increase community resilience against such extreme events, building engineers and architects must select designs that will perform satisfactorily under any and all hazard scenarios that may occur during a building's lifetime. Designers of resilient and sustainable buildings must therefore balance multiple competing interests. They must minimize both initial construction impacts and reconstruction impacts associated with unknown future extreme events. They must make tradeoffs between designs that optimize for one hazard to the detriment of performance under a different hazard. Finally, they must account for interdependencies within and between hazards and building performance, such as the effect of a natural hazard event on long-term durability as well as performance during a subsequent event. This research will investigate an integrated framework to support early building design decisions by identifying building systems that are consistent with stakeholder preferences and optimal over multiple hazards as well as multiple indicators of resiliency and sustainability. The decision support system will synthesize best practices in building design and research in performance-based design, life-cycle assessment, and decision support methodologies. Results of this research will inform the design of mid-rise commercial buildings exposed to coastal and seismic hazards. These buildings are essential to community and governmental disaster-response functions as well as community economic resiliency. Educational and outreach activities will increase awareness of multi-hazard resiliency and sustainability issues in practice and graduate study, will foster interest in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics fields among K-12 and undergraduate students, including three research experiences for undergraduate students supported annually, and will enhance the diversity of the science and engineering student community.

Currently available methods adequately address the independent design of resilient and sustainable soil, foundation, structure, and envelope (SFSE) building subsystems. However, an integrated decision support methodology is required to account for interdependencies between hazards and SFSE system performance.  An outcome of this research will be a decision support framework for multi-hazard building design that will provide robust estimates of resiliency and full life-cycle sustainability over a broad set of SFSE systems and multiple hazards. The decision support framework will integrate the full spectrum of hazard intensity as well as interdependent hazards and performance to identify optimal and preference-consistent candidate SFSE systems. Assessment of SFSE systems will occur in three phases: (1) generation of site-appropriate SFSE alternatives using a rating method to identify applicable systems and their subsystem interdependencies, (2) probabilistic multi-hazard resiliency and sustainability performance assessment based on site- and SFSE-specific hazard, fragility, and loss curves, and (3) multi-objective and multi-criteria optimization of performance metrics to prioritize candidate systems. This research will create the decision framework and develop methodologies for incorporating hazards and SFSE systems, generate models and datasets for mid-rise office buildings under hurricane, earthquake and tsunami hazards, study the sensitivity of results to uncertainty, and apply the framework to a case study building.

por.por_cntn:
Early design is the most critical stage to shape a building's performance across the different domains of hazard and environmental impacts. Therefore, selecting the best combination of building subsystems would ensure that the later stages of design yield a product that meets both stakeholder?s preferences and community goals in terms of resiliency and sustainability. Nonetheless, selecting optimal subsystem combinations is an arduous task due to the incomplete knowledge at early design stages, the dynamic nature of early design, and the inherent limitation of human-based decision making.

The VT-RSB project proposed a cross-disciplinary design support system for identifying optimal foundation-structure-envelope (FSE) combinations at a fixed location. The proposed framework incorporates different stakeholders? preferences into the early design process, and considers various sources of uncertainties in design formulations, hazard characterization, modeling, and decision-making. Therefore, the framework generates early design guidance to achieve a performance level beyond building codes objectives. The proposed framework is supported on open databases/software and a modular architecture to maximize customizability and automation for different hazards and building types.    

The VT-RSB framework comprises three independent modules, as shown in Figure 1: (1) SFLE generator, (2) life cycle performance assessment, and (3) Optimization and ranking modules. Prior to the application of modules, the designer needs to frame the early design decision-making problem. An interactive tool (i.e., SIMPLE-Design) was developed to aid designers by defining taxonomy and alternative SFLEs, selecting decision metrics (e.g., life cycle cost, global warming), determining performance range, and evaluating stakeholders' preferences. The first module (i.e., SFLE generator) then performs a series of convergence (i.e., removing unsatisfactory alternatives) and divergence (i.e., expanding the design space by introducing new alternatives) cycles based on the decision framing. Several open databases were also developed to support the SFLE generator module (e.g., INSSEPT). Next, the second module quantifies the performance of the selected alternative over their entire life cycle. As part of the second module, novel algorithms and tools were developed to improve seismic performance assessment. In addition, a data-driven methodology was developed to map early design parameters to performance endpoint metrics through machine learning models. Lastly, the produced assessment data by the first two modules are aggregated in a multi-objective optimization module to probabilistically evaluate the likelihood of meeting a stakeholder's preference with respect to a given performance objective.

The VT-RSB framework aimed to lay the foundation for the next generation of holistic design methodologies that address multi-hazard resiliency and sustainability. From a cross-disciplinary perspective, the VT-RSB project connected multiple critical research areas in disaster risk management, climate change adaptation, and commercial sector resiliency to infrastructure design and assessment. The developed method bridges the current performance-based methodologies to higher-level societal needs. Ultimately, the project outcomes are expected to lead to a more effective design and assessment approach that will save lives during disasters, protect communities economic hubs, and reduces environmental impacts of new constructions. The VT-RSB project involved faculty, graduate, and undergraduate students across different departments at Virginia Tech, and supported six Ph.D. and  four Master students, as well as five undergraduates research students (REU). In addition, the results of this research were published in 12 journal papers and 13 peer-reviewed conference publications.
